newsitem.title: UK: British Airways in talks to sell Ground Fleet Services.
newsitem.headline: British Airways in talks to sell Ground Fleet Services.

text.p: British Airways Plc said Monday it was in talks with a number of interested parties about the potential sales of its Ground Fleet Services operation based at London's Heathrow and Gatwick airports.
It said the potential sale is part of the airline's ambitious efficiency Programme announced earlier this year, which aims to find a billion sterling in annual cost savings over the next three years.
Ground Fleet Services employs 470 and provides specialist ground equipment and leased vehicles to operators at both airports, maintaining a fleet of 7,300 vehicles.

British Airways said if a sale was concluded most staff would transfer to the new company, although some may be offered voluntary severance or early retirement. It said a firm decision on the future of the unit was expected in the new year.
"The potential buyers are world class operators in their own right and would, therefore, we believe, be good employers," chief executive Robert Ayling said in a statement.

"We believe today's announcement presents the best way forward for Ground Fleet Services and its employees, who would benefit from the focus and expertise of a company which specialises in this business," he said.
"We are committed to ensuring that employees of Ground Fleet Services are treated in the best possible way."
The move follows British Airway's decision in September to close its Contract Handling unit at Heathrow providing ticketing, check-in, cargo and other services for other airlines at the airport.
